prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not wanting to give up some of my time with my son.
A bit of background on myself, I have been separated from my baby mother since just after our son was born, so about 3 years. I have a court order in place, that sets my parent time with him for every weekend. Baby mother approached me at drop off last night saying she, wants me to give up every second weekend to her, because she says she doesn’t get enough time with him. Now I understand wanting to be with him more and all but, she already has him for 22/30 days of a month whereas I get 8/30.. Her reasoning is that she’s in school right now which makes finding time for him hard but I just don’t want to lose any of my time with my boy, I look forward to every weekend with him and we have tons of fun. Am I the asshole for not wanting to give up any of my time to her?? 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the person in the situation is in the wrong. The parent has a court order for every weekend with their son. The other parent wants every second weekend because she's in school and finds it hard. The current arrangement is 8 days a month for the author and 22 for the other parent.

First, I need to consider legal aspects. There's a court order, so changing it would require legal action. The author isn't obligated to give up time unless there's a court modification. Legally, the author might not be in the wrong.

Emotionally and practically, the author values the time with their son and has a fixed schedule. The other parent's request could be due to her current circumstances, but the existing order already gives her majority time. The author's refusal isn't selfish if the court order is in place. It's about maintaining a structured visitation. Unless there's a valid reason to adjust the order, the author isn't violating anything by not changing their time. So the answer is B.
